title: Conditions for Two Categorical Variables
question_text:
To celebrate her school's $50\text{th}$ anniversary, the principal is ordering school-colored t-shirts for all the students at her school. Students will order a t-shirt, selecting a color (red or blue) and a size (small, medium, or large). Here is the distribution of t-shirt orders for a random sample of $178$ of the school's students:
The principal wants to test the claim $H_o$: Shirt Color and Size are independent. To do so, which of the following conditions must be met before the principal can use a $\chi^2$ procedure in this situation?

choices.text: The number of categories of shirt size must be large relative to the number of categories of t-shirt color.
Every student in the school must order a t-shirt; this way, the principal will have a completed order.
All expected counts must be at least $5$.
The distribution of shirt sizes must be approximately Normal.
All observed counts must be greater than $5$.

solution:
Solution

The students in the sample must be chosen randomly. Values in the sample must be independent from one another. The sample must be large enough to represent the population - to determine if the sample is large, all expected counts must be at least $5$.

Choice 'C' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect: In a chi-square setting, there is no requirement for the number of categories.

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect: If every student ordered a shirt, the principal would have the results of a census. No inference would need to be done, as the results of every student at the school would be recorded.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect: The chi-square distribution is a family of right-skewed density curves. Thus, the normal condition does not apply to chi-square settings.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect: One of the conditions for a chi-square hypothesis test is requiring all expected values to be at least $5$. The only requirement for an observed count is each observed count must be at least one.
